metadata.sermon_title: Trinity Sunday / Second Sunday After Pentecost
metadata.sermon_start_end: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent of a child, or young person, who appears to be on the verge of self-destruction. [...] with him there is plenteous redemption, and he shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities. (130:7–8)

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The text provided appears to be two separate sermonettes or a fragmented teaching rather than a single sermon on one pericope. It jumps from 2 Corinthians to Psalm 130. It fails Dekker's requirement of one specific passage. It treats the Trinity as a 'theme' rather than extracting a unique word from the text.
quotes: The church that was breaking his heart is the one that gets the full Trinitarian blessing.
This is the movement of Psalm 130, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest of all the psalms.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Epistle or the Psalm. Identify what 2 Cor 13:13 says that is found nowhere else, rather than treating it as a general 'Trinitarian formula'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is some attention to the 'agonized' nature of 2 Corinthians and the liturgical history of Psalm 130. However, there is no engagement with the original languages or the specific theological architecture of the biblical books themselves.
quotes: The last four chapters of 2 Corinthians form the most agonized portion of the New Testament.
It is called De Profundis, 'out of the depths.' It begins at rock bottom.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical-theological context of the 'depths' in Israel's cultic life and the specific Greek nuances of 'koinonia' in the Corinthian context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application uses strong imagery (addiction, anorexia), which is concrete. However, it quickly pivots to generalities about 'human love' being a 'glimmer' of God's love, which borders on the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
quotes: Maybe he is hooked on drugs and failing in school, maybe she is anorexic and starving herself...
Human love is a glimmer of the full radiance of God’s love.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the 'vague, romanticized version of human love' the text itself warns against. Connect the 'depths' to specific contemporary forms of 'being lost in time'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon uses a 'sandwich' method: an opening illustration, then a bit of text, then a concluding thought. The hearer is not so much 'expounded' alongside the text as they are given an example to help them understand the text.
quotes: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent...
Reflect on your own life. Think about those people who have borne with you.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the exposition of the text itself be the application. Do not start with a human analogy to explain God; let the Word create its own reality.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon explicitly deals with 'misery' (the depths, the miserable offender) and 'redemption' (forgiveness, plenteous redemption). It avoids being overly objective.
quotes: the depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
With the Lord there is mercy; with him there is plenteous redemption.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' section. The transition to 'joyous and liberating knowledge' is brief and could be more substantively grounded in the Spirit's work.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: While 'self-destruction' and 'being lost' are mentioned, the sermon leans heavily toward a universalized 'love that persists in breaking through our resistance.' The radical 'either/or' of the two ways is softened.
quotes: the love that persists in breaking through our resistance, the love that is with us even into the last ditch of our messed-up lives.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the possibility of remaining in the 'depths' or the 'destruction' Paul fears for the Corinthians if they reject the apostolic word.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the telos, particularly in the Trinity section. However, the connection between the 'miserable offender' in Psalm 130 and the specific work of Christ is somewhat externalized.
quotes: The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ... Christ is the telos of the sermon.
the love that has become incarnate in history through Jesus Christ.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how Christ specifically fulfills the 'plenteous redemption' of Psalm 130, rather than just mentioning His name as a concluding formula.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The text is approximately 1400-1500 words. At a standard preaching pace, this is roughly 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition. The sermon moves too quickly from the biblical text to general reflections on human relationships.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of focus on a single pericope and its insufficient length. It functions more as a series of theological reflections than a concentrated 'recreation of the Bible into a new, current word.' While it handles the 'three parts' (misery, redemption, gratitude) with more honesty than many modern sermons, it relies too heavily on human analogies (the parent/child) to bridge the gap to the Divine.
strengths: Honest treatment of human misery and the 'miserable offender' concept.
Concrete contemporary imagery in the introduction.
Clear Trinitarian focus that avoids mere abstraction.
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific Bible passage (Thesis 1).
Insufficient length to achieve true homiletical depth (Thesis 8).
Over-reliance on general truths about 'human love' as a proxy for God's love.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It is a substantive theological address, but it lacks the formal rigor of sustained exposition and the specific 'nowhere else' quality required of a true proclamatory word.
